makers.displaydate: 1840–1930; born Hartfield, England; died New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Charles Herbert Moore, 1840–1930; born Hartfield, England; died New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: Moore emerged in the 1860s as a leading figure in the Pre-Raphaelite movement dedicated to the teachings of John Ruskin, a British artist, author, and educator whose five-volume treatise Modern Painters (1843–60) had become influential with the American public. Ruskin’s distaste for industrial progress led him to propose an appreciation of nature, craftsmanship, and art history as the moral foundation for modern culture. Moore set aside his promising career as a landscape painter in 1871 to accept an appointment as a professor of drawing and medieval architecture at Harvard University. Taking a sabbatical from his teaching in 1877–78, Moore traveled to England to meet Ruskin and accompanied him on a trip throughout Italy sketching Gothic architecture, passing through the remote Swiss village at Simplon Pass on the Italian border.
artist's family; gift of Miss Elizabeth Huntington Moore, the artist's daughter, presented by Mrs. Frank Jewett Mather, Jr.
